If you say something about a user regarding a post that is obviously wrong, yet you don't think it's wrong, it is that lying? 
 
 If Bill thought that Jill believed that selling beer was good and said that she thought it was good after citing that Jill wrote beer shouldn't be sold, would Bill be lying if he thought that it was true?
also, what is the difference between lying and deliberately fabricateing a false, fradulent statement as to what a user's posts said and what they believe?

If you say something about a user regarding a post that is obviously wrong, yet you don't think it's wrong, it is that lying?
 Nope, it's misunderstanding. The fault is equally distributed then between the person who didn't write clearly enough and the person too lazy to give the writer the benefit of careful reading. 
 
If Bill thought that Jill believed that selling beer was good and said that she thought it was good after citing that Jill wrote beer shouldn't be sold, would Bill be lying if he thought that it was true?
 Bill wouldn't be lying if he thought that it was true. Bill would be stupid and lazy. Stupid for not being able to read effectively. Lazy for not taking simple steps to make sure that what Bill thought was true actually was true.

also, what is the difference between lying and deliberately fabricateing a false, fradulent statement as to what a user's posts said and what they believe?
 That's easy to check, by the process of 'conceptual analysis'. Simply take a dictionary and substitute synonyms for 'lying' and 'false' and 'fraudulent' and 'fabricating'. If the synonyms change, but the meaning doesn't, then there is no semantic difference.
